blueprint.label: Blueprints Visual Scripting
blueprint.description: Blueprints are UE5's node-based visual scripting system, allowing designers and artists to create gameplay logic without writing C++ code.
keySteps: Right-click in Content Browser → Blueprint Class → select parent (Actor, Pawn, etc.)
Open the Blueprint Editor and switch to the Event Graph tab
Right-click the graph to add nodes — use the search bar to find functions
Drag from pins to create connections between nodes
Use 'Event BeginPlay' for initialization and 'Event Tick' for per-frame logic
Compile and Save, then drag the Blueprint into your level to test

cast.label: Blueprint Casting
cast.description: Official documentation covering casting in blueprints.
keySteps: Drag from an object reference pin and search for 'Cast To [ClassName]'
Connect the object you want to cast on the input pin
Use the 'As [ClassName]' output pin to access class-specific functions
Handle the 'Cast Failed' execution pin for safety
Prefer Interfaces over casting when possible to reduce hard dependencies

material.label: Materials
material.description: Official documentation covering unreal engine materials.
keySteps: Start with the pages linked in the Getting Started section.
Read the Essential Material Concepts and Physically Based Materials pages to introduce the theory and ideas that form the foundation of Material creation in Unreal.
Use the Material Editor User Guide to learn practical aspects of using the Material Editor.
Explore Material Instances and Material Functions to optimize your workflow to save time and avoid doing the same work twice.

lumen.label: Lumen Global Illumination
lumen.description: Lumen provides fully dynamic global illumination and reflections, enabling realistic lighting that reacts to scene and geometry changes in real time.
keySteps: Enable Lumen from the Project Settings under the Rendering > Dynamic Global Illumination and Reflections categories.
Set Dynamic Global Illumination to Lumen.
Set Reflection Method to Lumen.
Ensure that Generate Mesh Distance Fields is enabled.

nanite.label: Nanite Virtualized Geometry
nanite.description: Nanite is UE5's virtualized geometry system that intelligently streams and renders billions of polygons in real time with automatic LOD management.
keySteps: Import a mesh and check the box for Build Nanite.
In the Content Browser, select Static or Skeletal Mesh Assets, right-click, and choose Nanite > Enable from the context menu.
Open a mesh's asset editor and enable Nanite through its Details panel.
In the Static Mesh Editor, locate the Nanite Settings and check the box for Enable Nanite Support.
In the Skeletal Mesh Editor, locate the Nanite Settings and check the box for Enable Nanite Support.
In the Geometry Collections Editor, locate the Nanite section and check the box for Enable Nanite.

niagara.label: Niagara Visual Effects
niagara.description: Niagara is UE5's modular VFX system for creating particle effects, simulations, and data-driven visual effects with full GPU acceleration.
keySteps: Check out the Getting Started section for a high-level overview of the Niagara Editor.
Read the Quick Start Guide.
Learn the Key Concepts and design philosophy behind Niagara.
Check out the Tutorials section for step-by-step project guides.
Use the Niagara Script Editor to adjust existing modules or create your own.

landscape.label: Landscape System
landscape.description: Covers UE5's terrain system for creating and sculpting large outdoor environments with multiple material layers and LOD support.
keySteps: Sculpt your Landscape Actors
Create customized Materials
Paint them on your Landscape

animation.label: Skeletal Mesh Animation
animation.description: Official documentation covering skeletal mesh animation system.

sequencer.label: Sequencer Cinematics
sequencer.description: Sequencer is UE5's cinematic editor for creating cutscenes, in-game cinematics, and timeline-based animations.
keySteps: Click the Cinematics dropdown in the Level Editor's main toolbar and select Add Level Sequence.
Create a new Level Sequence Asset in the Content Browser, give it a name, and click Save.
Navigate to the Place Actors panel and drag in a Level Sequence Actor from the Cinematic category.
Bind your Level Sequence Asset to the Level Sequence Actor by dragging and dropping the Asset onto the Level Sequence property.

collision.label: Collision & Physics
collision.description: Official documentation on Collision & Physics (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Set collision presets on your actors via Details → Collision section
Choose between Simple (primitives) and Complex (per-poly) collision
Use Collision Channels and Object Types to control what interacts with what
Set responses to Ignore, Overlap, or Block per channel
Add collision components (Box, Sphere, Capsule) for triggers and hit detection
Use 'Show Collision' in the viewport to visualize collision shapes

widget.label: UMG UI Designer
widget.description: Official documentation on UMG UI Designer.

umg.label: UMG UI Designer
umg.description: Unreal Motion Graphics (UMG/UMG UI) is UE5's widget-based system for building in-game HUDs, menus, and interactive UI elements.
keySteps: Create a Widget Blueprint from Content Browser → User Interface → Widget Blueprint
Design your UI in the Designer tab using Canvas Panel, Text, Buttons, etc.
Use Anchors to make widgets responsive to different screen sizes
Switch to the Graph tab to add interaction logic (button clicks, animations)
Create the widget in your Player Controller with 'Create Widget' → 'Add to Viewport'
Use Bindings or Event Dispatchers to update UI from game data

packaging.label: Packaging Projects
packaging.description: Official documentation covering packaging unreal engine projects (part of the optimization subsystem).

lighting.label: Lighting & Shadows
keySteps: Place a Directional Light for your sun — set Mobility to Movable for dynamic shadows
Add a Sky Light with 'Real Time Capture' enabled for ambient lighting
Use Point Lights and Spot Lights for interior and accent lighting
Enable Lumen for dynamic GI, or use baked lightmaps for static scenes
Adjust light Intensity, Color Temperature, and Attenuation Radius
Use a Post Process Volume to fine-tune exposure, bloom, and tone mapping

metahuman.label: MetaHuman
metahuman.description: Official documentation covering metahuman documentation (part of the animation subsystem).

control rig.label: Control Rig
control rig.description: Official documentation on Control Rig (part of the animation subsystem).
keySteps: Create a Control Rig Asset.
Learn about the various features of Control Rig.
Learn about the various tools and areas in the Control Rig Editor.
Enable Animation Mode to provide an animator-friendly workspace and tools in Unreal Engine.

datasmith.label: Datasmith
datasmith.description: Official documentation covering datasmith overview. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the tools subsystem).

multiplayer.label: Networking & Multiplayer
multiplayer.description: Official documentation covering networking and multiplayer.

metasound.label: MetaSounds Audio
metasound.description: MetaSounds is a high-performance, node-based audio system for procedural sound design and dynamic music in UE5.

world partition.label: World Partition
world partition.description: Official documentation on World Partition (part of the world_building subsystem).
keySteps: Open the File menu and select New Level.
Select the Open World map type.
Click the Create button to create a new map.
Open a Command Prompt window in Windows.
Navigate to the location of the UnrealEditor.exe executable file.
Begin the command with the name of the .exe file that will run the commandlet, UnrealEditor.exe

enhanced input.label: Enhanced Input System
enhanced input.description: Official documentation covering enhanced input (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Create input assets from the Content Browser, by clicking Add ( + ) and navigating to the Input category.
Create an Input Mapping Context by right-clicking the Context Browser, expanding the Input option, and choosing Input Mapping Context.
Add Input Listeners in either Blueprints or C++ when the Input Action's state changes.
Apply Input Mapping Contexts to a local player through its Enhanced Input Local Player Subsystem, and prioritize them to resolve collisions between multiple Actions trying to consume the same input.

path tracer.label: Path Tracer
path tracer.description: Official documentation on Path Tracer (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Set Default RHI to DirectX 12 in Platforms > Windows > Targeted RHIs.
Enable Support Hardware Ray Tracing in Engine > Rendering > Hardware Ray Tracing.
Enable Path Tracing in Engine > Rendering > Hardware Ray Tracing.
Enable Support Compute Skin Cache in Engine > Rendering > Optimizations.
Restart the engine for changes to take effect.
Enable the Path Tracer view in the Level Viewport by using the View Modes dropdown menu to select Path Tracing.

foliage.label: Foliage Tool
foliage.description: Official documentation on Foliage Tool (part of the world_building subsystem).

c++.label: C++ Programming
c++.description: Official documentation covering unreal engine cpp programming tutorials. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the general subsystem).

virtual production.label: Virtual Production
virtual production.description: Official documentation on Virtual Production (part of the cinematics subsystem).

artificial_intelligence.label: Artificial Intelligence in Unreal Engine
artificial_intelligence.description: Official documentation covering artificial intelligence (part of the ai subsystem).

behavior_trees.label: Behavior Trees
behavior_trees.description: Official documentation on Behavior Trees (part of the ai subsystem).

animation_basics.label: Animation Basics
animation_basics.description: Official documentation covering unreal engine animation basics. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system.

working_with_audio.label: Working with Audio
working_with_audio.description: Official documentation on Working with Audio.

motion_design.label: Motion Design (Avalanche)
motion_design.description: Official documentation covering motion design (part of the general subsystem).
keySteps: Use the reworked world outliner.
Use the user interface.
Use the rigging tools.
Use cloners.
Use customizable 2D/3D shapes.
Create materials using a streamlined, layer-based workflow called Material Designer.

blueprint_best_practices.label: Blueprint Best Practices
blueprint_best_practices.description: Official documentation on Blueprint Best Practices.
keySteps: Create reusable behavior in your project using Blueprint Classes.
Add variables using the Blueprint Editor My Blueprint Panel tab.
Use local variables within functions to reduce clutter.
Use class variables for things you want to access from multiple places in the Blueprint.
Use the Search button in the Blueprint Editor to find variables, functions, or comments.

chaos_physics.label: Chaos Physics
chaos_physics.description: Chaos is UE5's built-in physics and destruction system, handling rigid body simulation, cloth, vehicles, and real-time destruction.

chaos_destruction.label: Chaos Destruction
chaos_destruction.description: Official documentation on Chaos Destruction (part of the gameplay subsystem).

working_with_content.label: Data Pipelines
working_with_content.description: Official documentation covering working with content (part of the general subsystem).

rendering_and_graphics.label: Rendering and Graphics
rendering_and_graphics.description: Official documentation on Rendering and Graphics.

movie_render_queue.label: Movie Render Queue
movie_render_queue.description: Official documentation on Movie Render Queue (part of the rendering subsystem).

5_documentation.label: Unreal Engine 5 Documentation
5_documentation.description: Official documentation on Unreal Engine 5 Documentation (part of the foundation subsystem).

understanding_the_basics_of_unreal_engin.label: Understanding the Basics
understanding_the_basics_of_unreal_engin.description: Official documentation covering understanding the basics of unreal engine. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the foundation subsystem).
keySteps: Download and install Unreal Engine from the Epic Games Launcher.
Become familiar with the major components of the Unreal Editor interface.
Learn how to work with Assets in the Content Browser.
Customize Unreal Engine's layout, keybindings, and behavior.
Learn how to work with Unreal projects.

modeling_mode_overview.label: Modeling Mode Overview
modeling_mode_overview.description: Official documentation on Modeling Mode Overview. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the tools subsystem).

hair_rendering_and_simulation.label: Hair Rendering and Simulation
hair_rendering_and_simulation.description: Official documentation on Hair Rendering and Simulation.

water_system.label: Water System
water_system.description: Official documentation on Water System (part of the world_building subsystem).
keySteps: Use Edit > Plugins to open the Plugins browser.
Search for the Water plugin and check its box to enable it.
Restart the editor for changes to take effect.
Select View Options (located in the bottom-right) and check the boxes next to Show Engine Content and Show Plugin Content.

lighting_the_environment.label: Lighting the Environment
lighting_the_environment.description: Official documentation on Lighting the Environment.

materials_and_shaders.label: Materials and Shaders
materials_and_shaders.description: Official documentation on Materials and Shaders.

material_inputs.label: Material Inputs
material_inputs.description: Official documentation on Material Inputs (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: Change Material properties in the Details panel.
Observe inputs on the Main Material Node turning white (enabled) or grayed out (disabled).
Adjust Blend Mode, Shading Model, and Material Domain properties to enable desired inputs.
Use the Tangent input to define light directionality with a texture or Vector expression.

niagara_visual_effects.label: Niagara Visual Effects
niagara_visual_effects.description: Official documentation on Niagara Visual Effects (part of the vfx subsystem).

testing_and_optimizing_your_content.label: Testing and Optimization
testing_and_optimizing_your_content.description: Official documentation covering testing and optimizing your content. Covers advanced concepts and implementation details (part of the general subsystem).

unreal_insights.label: Unreal Insights
unreal_insights.description: Official documentation on Unreal Insights (part of the optimization subsystem).
keySteps: Open Unreal Insights. This will start the Unreal Trace Server, if not already running, on Windows, Mac, or Linux

Click on the Manage store settings dropdown button then modify the default store directory by clicking the "Set Trace Store directory" button. When starting a new trace the file will be stored in this directory.
The old trace store directory is automatically added to watch folders.
Add one or more watch folders by clicking the Add directory button. If the new folder contains trace files they will appear in the session list with an icon colored by a unique color.

programming_with_c_plus_plus.label: Programming with C++
programming_with_c_plus_plus.description: Official documentation covering programming with c plus plus (part of the general subsystem).

cinematics_and_sequencer.label: Cinematics and Sequencer
cinematics_and_sequencer.description: Official documentation on Cinematics and Sequencer.

in_camera_vfx.label: In-Camera VFX
in_camera_vfx.description: Official documentation covering in camera vfx (part of the cinematics subsystem).

editor_interface.label: Unreal Engine Editor Interface
editor_interface.description: Official documentation on Unreal Engine Editor Interface (part of the tools subsystem).

umg_ui_designer.label: UMG UI Designer
umg_ui_designer.description: Official documentation on UMG UI Designer.

building_virtual_worlds.label: Building Virtual Worlds
building_virtual_worlds.description: Official documentation on Building Virtual Worlds (part of the world_building subsystem).

procedural_content_generation_overview.label: PCG (Procedural Content Generation)
procedural_content_generation_overview.description: Official documentation covering procedural content generation overview. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the world_building subsystem).

virtual_shadow_maps.label: Virtual Shadow Maps
virtual_shadow_maps.description: Virtual Shadow Maps provide high-resolution, efficient shadow rendering that works with Nanite geometry for consistent shadow quality.
keySteps: Enable Virtual Shadow Maps in Project Settings under Engine > Rendering in the Shadows section.
Alternatively, use the console variable r.Shadow.Virtual.Enable to enable VSMs.
Adjust the number of rays used for penumbra shadows with console variables r.Shadow.Virtual.SMRT.RayCountLocal and r.Shadow.Virtual.SMRT.RayCountDirectional.
Adjust Source Radius on local lights or Source Angle on Directional Lights to control shadow rays distribution.

animation_blueprints.label: Animation Blueprints
keySteps: In the Content Browser, click Add (+), then select Animation > Animation Blueprint.
Specify which Skeleton to target for the Animation Blueprint and click Create.
Right-click on a Skeletal Mesh Asset in the Content Browser and select Create > Anim Blueprint.
Double-click your new Animation Blueprint to open it in the Animation Blueprint Editor.
Select your Skeletal Mesh and set Animation Mode to Use Animation Blueprint.
Set Anim Class to your Animation Blueprint asset.

material_editor_fundamentals.label: Material Editor Fundamentals
material_editor_fundamentals.description: Official documentation on Material Editor Fundamentals (part of the materials subsystem).

static_mesh_editor_reference.label: Static Mesh Editor Reference
static_mesh_editor_reference.description: Official documentation on Static Mesh Editor Reference (part of the tools subsystem).

mobile_feature_levels_and_rendering_mode.label: Mobile Feature Levels And Rendering Modes
mobile_feature_levels_and_rendering_mode.description: Official documentation on Mobile Feature Levels And Rendering Modes.
keySteps: Add the following CVar to your DefaultEngine.ini: r.Mobile.ShadingPath=1
To enable the desktop renderer for iOS, open your Project Settings, then navigate to Platforms > iOS > Rendering and enable Metal Desktop Renderer
To enable the desktop renderer for Android Vulkan, navigate to Platforms > Android > Build and enable Support Vulkan Desktop [Experimental]
Set r.Android.DisableVulkanSM5Support to 0 to allow the use of SM5
Restart the Unreal Editor for your changes to take effect

landscape_collision_guide.label: Landscape Collision Guide
landscape_collision_guide.description: Official documentation on Landscape Collision Guide (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Select your Landscape Terrain in the Editor viewport.
In the Details panel, expand the Collision section.
Find the Collision Mip Level option under the Collision section.
Set the value from 0 to 5 and then press the Enter key to apply the change.

level_editor.label: Level Editor
level_editor.description: Official documentation on Level Editor (part of the tools subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Modes dropdown in the Level Editor Toolbar.
Activate a mode by clicking its icon or using the Shift + Number shortcut.
Close a panel by clicking the small "X" in the upper-right corner of the tab.
Hide a panel by right-clicking on the tab, and then clicking Hide Tab on the context menu that appears.
Reopen a closed panel by clicking that panel's name on the Window menu.

content_browser.label: Content Browser
content_browser.description: Official documentation on Content Browser (part of the tools subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Content Browser from the Window menu in the top menu bar.
Open the Content Browser from the Create menu on the Main Toolbar.
Open the Content Browser by clicking the Content Drawer button on the bottom toolbar of the editor.
Click and drag to re-dock the Content Browser anywhere within the editor, or float it as its own window.
Right-click the Content Browser tab and select Move to Sidebar to collapse the Content Browser to a clickable tab in the left-hand sidebar of the Unreal Editor window.

sequencer_cinematic_editor.label: Sequencer Cinematic Editor
sequencer_cinematic_editor.description: Official documentation on Sequencer Cinematic Editor (part of the cinematics subsystem).

actor_programming.label: Actor Programming
actor_programming.description: Official documentation on Actor Programming (part of the gameplay subsystem).

getting_started_with_unreal_engine.label: Getting Started With Unreal Engine
getting_started_with_unreal_engine.description: Official documentation on Getting Started With Unreal Engine. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the foundation subsystem).

procedural_content_generation_pcg_biome_.label: Procedural Content Generation Pcg Biome Core And Sample Plugins
procedural_content_generation_pcg_biome_.description: Official documentation on Procedural Content Generation Pcg Biome Core And Sample Plugins (part of the world_building subsystem).

pcg_editor_mode.label: Pcg Editor Mode
pcg_editor_mode.description: Official documentation on Pcg Editor Mode (part of the world_building subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Modes dropdown menu and select PCG to access the PCG editor mode.
Select a tool, noting that the results depend on whether you have an appropriate actor selected.
Click on a tool button to start using the tool, which displays the Apply and Cancel buttons and a secondary row of buttons for presets.
Adjust instance settings in the panel, such as the Tool Graph, Parameter Overrides, Data Instance, Actor Label, Component Name, and Actor Class to Spawn.

Set up a tool graph by looking in the PCG Graph settings in the Tool Data section and setting values like Display Name, Tooltip, Compatible Tool Tags, Initial Actor Class To Spawn, New Actor Label, and Is Preset.

assembly_pcg.label: Assembly Pcg
assembly_pcg.description: Official documentation on Assembly Pcg (part of the world_building subsystem).
keySteps: Create PCG point data from static meshes and instanced static meshes in a level using Asset Action > Create PCG Assets from Level(s).

5_7_documentation.label: Unreal Engine 5 7 Documentation
5_7_documentation.description: Official documentation on Unreal Engine 5 7 Documentation (part of the foundation subsystem).

PythonAPI.label: Pythonapi
PythonAPI.description: Official documentation on Pythonapi (part of the general subsystem).
keySteps: Access the Unreal Engine Python API Documentation via the provided link.

designing_visuals_rendering_and_graphics.label: Designing Visuals Rendering And Graphics With Unreal Engine
designing_visuals_rendering_and_graphics.description: Official documentation on Designing Visuals Rendering And Graphics With Unreal Engine.
keySteps: Learn about features, concepts, and tools used to design and develop your projects.
Set up and manage your textures and materials applied to surfaces.
Learn about conceptual lighting techniques that can be applied when building your virtual worlds.
Optimize and debug content for performance.

creating_user_interfaces_with_umg_and_sl.label: Creating User Interfaces With Umg And Slate
creating_user_interfaces_with_umg_and_sl.description: Official documentation on Creating User Interfaces With Umg And Slate (part of the ui subsystem).

gameplay_systems.label: Gameplay Systems
keySteps: Understand the class hierarchy: GameMode → GameState → PlayerController → Pawn/Character
GameMode defines rules (who spawns, win conditions) — lives on the server only
GameState replicates shared game data to all players
PlayerController handles input and camera — one per player
Pawn/Character is the physical actor in the world the player controls
Override these classes in your project to customize behavior

getting_started_with_mobile_development.label: Getting Started With Mobile Development
getting_started_with_mobile_development.description: Official documentation on Getting Started With Mobile Development. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the foundation subsystem).
keySteps: Create a Low-Overhead Mobile Project
Set up a low-overhead project with minimal rendering features for Android devices.
Learn how to build projects for iOS, iPadOS, and Apple TV.
Record the GPU states for your application in advance to optimize rendering.

actors_and_geometry.label: Actors And Geometry
actors_and_geometry.description: Official documentation on Actors And Geometry (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Place Actors into a Level (map)
Move and scale Actors to create an environment
Add script to make Actors behave the way you want

coordinate_system_and_spaces.label: Coordinate System And Spaces
coordinate_system_and_spaces.description: Official documentation on Coordinate System And Spaces (part of the general subsystem).
keySteps: Measure 2 unit steps along the positive X-axis.
Measure 1 unit step along the positive Y-axis.
Measure 3 unit steps along the negative Z-axis.
Use world space to translate or rotate an object in absolute units relative to the level's origin and scale relative to the entire level.
Use local space to translate or rotate an object relative to its parent.

tools_and_editors.label: Tools And Editors
tools_and_editors.description: Official documentation on Tools And Editors.
keySteps: Construct your gameplay levels in the Level Editor.
Preview the look, collision, and UV mapping of Static Meshes in the Static Mesh Editor.
Create and edit Materials in the Material Editor.
Work with and modify Blueprints in the Blueprint Editor.
Create Physics Assets for use with Skeletal Meshes in the Physics Asset Editor.

unreal_editor_interface.label: Unreal Editor Interface
unreal_editor_interface.description: Official documentation on Unreal Editor Interface (part of the tools subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Level Editor to access core creation functionality.
Use the Menu Bar to access common application actions.
Use the Main Toolbar for shortcuts to common tools and editors.
Use the Viewport Toolbar to manipulate objects in the level.

unreal_editor_preferences.label: Unreal Editor Preferences
unreal_editor_preferences.description: Official documentation on Unreal Editor Preferences (part of the tools subsystem).
keySteps: Click Edit > Editor Preferences to open the Editor Preferences window.
In the Editor Preferences dialog, scroll down to the Privacy category.
Click Bug Reports or Usage Data.
In the right pane, under Options, click Don't Send.

working_with_plugins.label: Working With Plugins
working_with_plugins.description: Official documentation on Working With Plugins (part of the tools subsystem).
keySteps: Go to Edit > Plugins to open the Plugins window.
Find the plugin you want to enable using the list or the Search box.
Click the checkbox next to the plugin to enable it.
Save your work, then restart Unreal Engine.

blueprint_variables.label: Blueprint Variables
keySteps: Right-click any input or output data pins on a Blueprint node and select Promote to Variable.
Click Class Defaults on the Blueprint Editor Toolbar to open the Defaults in the Details panel.
In the Details panel, enter the desired default values to the right of your variable name.
Right-click the variable name in the My Blueprint tab and select Rename in the menu that appears.
Type the new variable name in the text box and then press Enter.

introduction_to_blueprints_visual_script.label: Introduction To Blueprints Visual Scripting
introduction_to_blueprints_visual_script.description: Official documentation on Introduction To Blueprints Visual Scripting. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system.
keySteps: Reference and manipulate actors within the level.
Control cinematics using level sequence actors.
Manage level streaming.
Create customizable props that improve environment artists' workflows.
Manipulate camera behavior, set up input events for mouse, controller, and touch screens, and create an animation Blueprint asset for handling skeletal mesh animations.

material_editor_user_guide.label: Unreal Engine Material Editor User Guide
material_editor_user_guide.description: Official documentation on Unreal Engine Material Editor User Guide (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: Create a new Material asset in the Content Browser.
Open the Material Editor.
Place Material Expressions and Functions in the Material Graph.
Connect Material Expressions to inputs on the Main Material Node to define the Material's attributes.
Compile and Save the Material.
Apply the Material to objects in the Level.

instanced_materials.label: Instanced Materials
keySteps: Create parameters in the parent Material to make attributes editable within an instance.
Give every parameter a unique, descriptive name in the Details panel.
Open Material instances from the Content Browser.
Edit parameters in the Material Instance Editor.

control_rig_in_animation_blueprints.label: Control Rig In Animation Blueprints
control_rig_in_animation_blueprints.description: Official documentation on Control Rig In Animation Blueprints.
keySteps: Add a Control Rig node by right-clicking in the Anim Graph and selecting Misc > Control Rig.
Connect the source output to the result pose by connecting the pins.
Select the node, navigate to the Details panel, and select the Control Rig from the Control Rig Class property dropdown menu.
Expose Variables by ensuring they are instance-editable by clicking the Eye next to it in the Control Rig My Blueprint panel.
In the Animation Blueprint, select the Control Rig node and enable Use Pin on the Variable entry.

animating_with_control_rig.label: Animating With Control Rig
animating_with_control_rig.description: Official documentation on Animating With Control Rig (part of the animation subsystem).
keySteps: Drag the Control Rig Asset from the Content Browser into your level to open a new Sequencer and add the Skeletal Mesh with Control Rig tracks.
Alternatively, click the Add (+) Track button on the Skeletal Mesh Track, and select Control Rig > Control Rig Classes and select from the list of available Control Rig Classes.
Expand the Control Rig Track to reveal the list of controls that can be animated.
Keyframe controls similar to most objects in Sequencer, or press the S Key with a Control selected to create a Transform keyframe.
To set a Control Rig track to be a Layered Control Rig track, click the ( + ) Add Track button adjacent to the Skeletal Mesh track, then navigate to Control Rig > Layered and check the box.

behavior_tree___quick_start_guide.label: Behavior Tree   Quick Start Guide
behavior_tree___quick_start_guide.description: Official documentation on Behavior Tree   Quick Start Guide (part of the ai subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Content Drawer, then right-click on the ThirdPerson folder and create a New Folder called AI.
In the ThirdPerson > Blueprints folder, drag the BP_ThirdPersonCharacter onto the AI folder and select Copy Here.
In the AI folder, create a new Blueprint Class based on the AIController class.
Name the AIController Blueprint Enemy_Controller and the BP_ThirdPersonCharacter Blueprint Enemy_Character.
Open Enemy_Character, then delete all the script from the graph.
Select Class Defaults from the Toolbar, then in the Details panel, assign the Enemy_Controller as the AI Controller Class.

environment_query_system.label: Environment Query System
environment_query_system.description: Official documentation on Environment Query System (part of the general subsystem).

environment_query_system_overview.label: Environment Query System Overview
environment_query_system_overview.description: Official documentation on Environment Query System Overview. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the foundation subsystem).
keySteps: Create EQS Query assets in the Content Drawer.
Edit the EQS Query inside the Environmental Query Editor.
Add a Generator node to produce Items.
Add desired Tests to run on those Items.
Run the EQS Query through a Behavior Tree using the Run EQS Query Task node.

navigation_system.label: Navigation System
navigation_system.description: Official documentation on Navigation System (part of the general subsystem).

world_partitioned_navigation_mesh.label: World Partitioned Navigation Mesh
world_partitioned_navigation_mesh.description: Official documentation on World Partitioned Navigation Mesh (part of the world_building subsystem).
keySteps: Click File > New Level. Select the Open World map type and click Create. Save the level.
Click Settings > Project Settings to open the Project Settings window.
Click the Navigation Mesh category and scroll down to the Runtime section. Click the Runtime Generation dropdown and select Static.
Click Add + > Volumes > NavMeshBoundsVolume to add a Navigation Mesh volume actor to your level.
Select the RecastNavMesh-Default actor in the Outliner window and go to the Details panel. Scroll down to the Generation section and enable the Is World Partitioned Navmesh checkbox.
Enter the following console command in the command line and press Enter: n.bNavmeshAllowPartitionedBuildingFromEditor 1

physics.label: Physics
physics.description: Official documentation on Physics (part of the gameplay subsystem).

hardware_ray_tracing.label: Hardware Ray Tracing
hardware_ray_tracing.description: Official documentation on Hardware Ray Tracing (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Enable hardware ray tracing for your project in the Project Settings under Engine > Rendering > Hardware Ray Tracing.
Check the box for Support Hardware Ray Tracing.
Enable Support Compute Skin Cache if prompted.
Check Use Hardware Ray Tracing when available if using Lumen.
Set Ray Lighting Mode to Hit Lighting for Reflections if using Lumen and wanting higher quality reflections.

post_process_effects.label: Post Process Effects
post_process_effects.description: Official documentation on Post Process Effects (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Add a Post Process Volume into your Level using the Place Actors panel.
Use the Details panel to access all the available properties and features.
Toggle the Infinite Extent property to make this Post Process Volume affect everywhere in the scene, or leave it unchecked to have it affect only a certain area.
Configure default post process settings in the Project Settings in the Rendering > Default Settings section.

add_post_process_volumes.label: Add Post Process Volumes
add_post_process_volumes.description: Official documentation on Add Post Process Volumes (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: In the Outliner, search for the PostProcessVolume and select it.
Rename this volume PPV_Global.
In the Details panel, expand Post Process Volume Settings.
Verify that Infinite Extent (Unbound) is checked and Priority is set to 0.
In the Editor’s main toolbar, click Create > Visual Effects > Post Process Volume . Alternatively, you can search for it. Add two volumes.
Name the first volume PPV_Room3 and the second PPV_LevelTransition.

seeAlso.label: Artists Tools and Workflows for Rendering

world_partition___data_layers.label: World Partition   Data Layers
world_partition___data_layers.description: Official documentation on World Partition   Data Layers (part of the world_building subsystem).
keySteps: Enable World Partition in your map using Tools > Convert Level or by using the commandlet.
Create Data Layer Assets using the Data Layers Outliner or in the Content Browser.
Create Data Layer Instances in the Data Layers Outliner.
Open the Data Layers Outliner by selecting Window > World Partition > Data Layer Outliner.
Add selected Actors to the selected Data Layer Instance using the Data Layer Outliner context menu.

audio_analysis_and_visualization.label: Audio Analysis And Visualization
audio_analysis_and_visualization.description: Official documentation on Audio Analysis And Visualization.

audio_gameplay_volumes.label: Audio Gameplay Volumes
audio_gameplay_volumes.description: Official documentation on Audio Gameplay Volumes.

soundscape.label: Soundscape
soundscape.description: Official documentation on Soundscape (part of the audio subsystem).

waveform_editor_quick_start.label: Waveform Editor Quick Start
waveform_editor_quick_start.description: Official documentation on Waveform Editor Quick Start (part of the tools subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Plugin panel by selecting Edit > Plugins.
Search for the Waveform Editor plugin and select the corresponding checkbox to enable it.
Right-click the Sound Wave file you want to edit in the Content Browser.
Select Edit Waveform from the context menu to open the Waveform Editor.
Click Export Options and select your desired channel format.
Click the Export button and then click Save Selected in the Save Content window.

customizable_sequencer_track.label: Customizable Sequencer Track
customizable_sequencer_track.description: Official documentation on Customizable Sequencer Track. Covers advanced concepts and implementation details (part of the cinematics subsystem).
keySteps: Enable the Customizable Sequencer Track plugin from Edit > Plugins in the Runtime section, then restart Unreal Engine.
Create three new Blueprint classes, inheriting from SequencerSectionBP, SequencerTrackBP, and SequencerTrackInstanceBP.
Open the Blueprint that inherits from SequencerTrackBP and set Default Section Type to the Blueprint inheriting from SequencerSectionBP in the Class Defaults section of the Details panel.
Set Track Instance Type to the Blueprint inheriting from SequencerTrackInstanceBP in the Class Defaults section of the Details panel.
Open the Blueprint that inherits from SequencerTrackInstanceBP and override Events in the Functions section to add logic to the Event Graph.

getting_started_with_modeling_mode.label: Getting Started With Modeling Mode
getting_started_with_modeling_mode.description: Official documentation on Getting Started With Modeling Mode. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the tools subsystem).

introduction_to_geometry_scripting.label: Introduction To Geometry Scripting
introduction_to_geometry_scripting.description: Official documentation on Introduction To Geometry Scripting. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the tools subsystem).

scriptable_tools_system.label: Scriptable Tools System
scriptable_tools_system.description: Official documentation on Scriptable Tools System (part of the general subsystem).
keySteps: Select Edit > Plugins in the menu bar.
Type "scriptable tools" in the search bar.
Enable Scriptable Tools Editor Mode plugin, and select Yes in the dialog popup.
Click the Selection Mode dropdown in the Level Editor to access all scriptable tools from the Scriptable Tools editor mode.

landscape_edit_layers.label: Landscape Edit Layers
landscape_edit_layers.description: Official documentation on Landscape Edit Layers (part of the world_building subsystem).
keySteps: Add a new layer by selecting the + Icon on the right side of the Layers property.
Rename an Edit Layer by Right-Clicking on the layer and selecting Rename.
Lock layers by selecting the Lock icon.
Hide a layer by selecting the eye icon.
Change the blending for each layer by adding or subtracting from the Alpha value.

gpu_lightmass_global_illumination.label: Gpu Lightmass Global Illumination
gpu_lightmass_global_illumination.description: Official documentation on Gpu Lightmass Global Illumination (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Plugins tab from the Edit > Plugins menu.
Under the Built-In > Editor category, locate and enable GPU Lightmass .
Open the Project Settings window from the Edit > Project Settings menu.

Under the Engine > Rendering category, enable Hardware Ray Tracing > Support Hardware Ray Tracing and Virtual Textures > Enable Virtual Texture Support and Virtual Textures > Enable Virtual Texture Lightmaps
Under the Platforms > Windows category, set Targeted RHIs > Default RHI: DirectX 12
Restart the editor for these changes to take effect.

editor_utility_widgets.label: Editor Utility Widgets
editor_utility_widgets.description: Official documentation on Editor Utility Widgets (part of the ui subsystem).
keySteps: Right-click in the Content Browser and select Editor Utilities > Editor Utility Widget.
Name your Editor Utility Widget Asset.
Double-click the Editor Utility Widget Asset to open the Widget Blueprint for editing.
Edit your Widget Blueprint as needed.
Right-click the Editor Utility Widget Asset and select Run Editor Utility Widget to open an Editor tab with your Editor Utility displayed.

running_blueprints_at_unreal_editor_star.label: Running Blueprints At Unreal Editor Startup
running_blueprints_at_unreal_editor_star.description: Official documentation on Running Blueprints At Unreal Editor Startup.
keySteps: Right-click in the Content Browser and choose Editor Utility > Editor Utility Blueprint.
Choose a parent class. EditorUtilityObject is a safe choice, but you could choose any other class that derives from EditorUtilityObject. Click Create.

Override the Run function for the class by hovering over the Functions group in the My Blueprint panel until the Override button appears, then click the Override button and select Run from the dropdown list.
Find the DefaultEditorPerProjectUserSettings.ini file, which is located in your Project folder at Project/Config/DefaultEditorPerProjectUserSettings.ini. If this file does not exist, create it.
Find the following section of the file: [/Script/Blutility.EditorUtilitySubsystem]. If this section doesn't exist, create it.

For each Blueprint class that you want to act as a startup object, add the path to that class as a new value in the StartupObjects array. Start the path with /Game/, then add the path to the Blueprint class as shown in the Content Browser. Follow the object name with a period (.) character, then repeat the object name again.

exporting_datasmith_content_from_revit_t.label: Exporting Datasmith Content From Revit To Unreal Engine
exporting_datasmith_content_from_revit_t.description: Official documentation on Exporting Datasmith Content From Revit To Unreal Engine (part of the tools subsystem).
keySteps: In the Project Browser, select and open the 3D View that you want to export.
Open the Datasmith ribbon, then click Export 3D View.
In the Export 3D View to Unreal Datasmith window, browse to the location you want to save your .udatasmith file, and use the File Name box to give your new file a name.
Click Save.

seeAlso.label: Importing Datasmith Content into Unreal Engine

using_datasmith_at_runtime.label: Using Datasmith At Runtime
using_datasmith_at_runtime.description: Official documentation on Using Datasmith At Runtime (part of the tools subsystem).
keySteps: Create a new Actor Blueprint to contain the anchor point for the Datasmith content.
Select the Event Graph tab and remove every event except Event BeginPlay.
Drag a connection from Event BeginPlay and add the Spawn Actor From Class node.
Open the Class dropdown menu and select DatasmithRuntimeActor.
Promote the Return Value to a variable and name it Anchor.
Add a copy of your Anchor Blueprint to the level and press Play to test.

using_datasmith_direct_link.label: Using Datasmith Direct Link
using_datasmith_direct_link.description: Official documentation on Using Datasmith Direct Link (part of the tools subsystem).
keySteps: Download and install the appropriate Datasmith Exporter plugin for your application.
Ensure the Datasmith features are enabled in your 3D application.
Open your destination application and select your 3D application as the Source.
Sync your Direct Link connection by clicking the Synchronize with Direct Link button.
Right-click your project's executable file and, from the context menu, select Create Shortcut.
In the shortcut's Properties window, add the -messaging parameter to the Target property.

use_the_online_services_plugins.label: Use The Online Services Plugins
use_the_online_services_plugins.description: Official documentation on Use The Online Services Plugins (part of the tools subsystem).

container_deployments_and_images_for_unr.label: Container Deployments And Images For Unreal Editor And Unreal Engine
container_deployments_and_images_for_unr.description: Official documentation on Container Deployments And Images For Unreal Editor And Unreal Engine (part of the tools subsystem).

anatomy_of_a_blueprint.label: Anatomy Of A Blueprint
anatomy_of_a_blueprint.description: Official documentation on Anatomy Of A Blueprint.
keySteps: Create Blueprint Classes to add functionality on top of existing gameplay classes.
Use Components to build up reusable Blueprints to accelerate your level design process.
Use the Construction Script to dynamically adjust the look and feel of the new Object or Actor.
Use the EventGraph to add functionality that is common to all instances of a Blueprint.
Use Functions and Macros to reuse sections of script.

basic_scripting_with_blueprints.label: Basic Scripting With Blueprints
basic_scripting_with_blueprints.description: Official documentation on Basic Scripting With Blueprints.

blueprint_communication_usage.label: Blueprint Communication Usage
blueprint_communication_usage.description: Official documentation on Blueprint Communication Usage.
keySteps: Use Direct Actor communication to share information between Actors in your Level.
Use Event Dispatchers to tell other "listening" Blueprints that an event has happened.
Use Blueprint Interfaces for a common method of interacting with multiple types of objects that all share some specific functionality.
Use Cast nodes to ask the object "are you a special version of that object" and if so let me access you, if not then disregard my request.

blueprint_debugger.label: Blueprint Debugger
keySteps: Open the Blueprint Debugger window from the Tools menu, or from the Debug menu within the Blueprint Editor.
Place a Breakpoint on a node by right-clicking the node and selecting Add Breakpoint from the context menu.
Disable a Breakpoint temporarily by right-clicking either the Blueprint node, or the Breakpoint's entry in the Debugger window, and selecting Disable Breakpoint from the context menu.
Begin watching a pin by right-clicking the pin's name in the Blueprint Graph and selecting Watch this value from the context menu.

blueprint_editor_cheat_sheet.label: Blueprint Editor Cheat Sheet
blueprint_editor_cheat_sheet.description: Official documentation on Blueprint Editor Cheat Sheet.
keySteps: Select Node: Click on a Node
Add to Selection: Shift + Click on a Node
Toggle Selection: Ctrl + Click on a Node
Marquee Select (Replace): Left Mouse Button (LMB) Drag

blueprint_interface.label: Blueprint Interface
keySteps: Click the Add button in the Content Browser, then select Blueprints > Blueprint Interface.
Right-click in the Content Browser, then select Blueprints > Blueprint Interface.
In the My Blueprint tab, create a new function by clicking on the + icon on the functions list header.
In the My Blueprint pane, enter a name for the new function.
In the Details tab, scroll to the Inputs category and click the + icon to create a new Input Parameter.
Set the Input Name and Type as desired.

blueprint_namespaces.label: Blueprint Namespaces
keySteps: Open the Content Drawer and double-click your Blueprint to open its Class Defaults.
From the ToolBar, click the Class Settings and navigate to the Details panel Blueprint Options > Blueprint Namespace category, then type your namespace into the text field.
From the Toolbar, click Compile and Save.

Navigate to Edit > Editor Preferences > Content Editors > Blueprint Editor > Experimental, and from the Namespaces to Always Include field, click the Add ( + ) button to add your namespace as an element to the list.
Navigate to the Edit > Project Settings > Editor > Blueprint Project Settings > Experimental, then in the Namespaces to Always Include Array List, click Add ( + ) to add your namespace to the list.

blueprint_workflows.label: Blueprint Workflows
keySteps: Create Macros to check conditions.
Create Functions to perform actions.
Set and Get Actor References to manipulate actors.
Place Nodes to build logic.
Collapse Graphs into reusable components.
Connect Nodes to define execution flow.

overview_of_blueprints_visual_scripting.label: Overview Of Blueprints Visual Scripting
overview_of_blueprints_visual_scripting.description: Official documentation on Overview Of Blueprints Visual Scripting. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system.

quick_start_guide_for_blueprints_visual_.label: Quick Start Guide For Blueprints Visual Scripting
quick_start_guide_for_blueprints_visual_.description: Official documentation on Quick Start Guide For Blueprints Visual Scripting.
keySteps: Create a new project from the Games category that uses the Side Scroller, Blueprint, and With Starter Content settings.
In the Main Toolbar, press the Modes button, and from the dropdown click on Select to display the Place Actors panel.
In the Details panel, click on the Blueprint/Add Script button.
Double-click the Blueprint Class in the Content Browser.
First, select the Box component in the Components tab.
Expand the Add Event for Box dropdown, and then Collision, then select On Component Begin Overlap.

specialized_blueprint_visual_scripting_n.description: Official documentation on Specialized Blueprint Visual Scripting Node Groups.

user_interface_reference_for_the_bluepri.description: Official documentation on User Interface Reference For The Blueprints Visual Scripting Editor.

control_rig_editor.label: Control Rig Editor
control_rig_editor.description: Official documentation on Control Rig Editor (part of the animation subsystem).
keySteps: Compile the Control Rig to save changes and execute logic.
Use the Solve Direction button to switch between different Solver event chains and preview them.
Enable Auto Compile to automatically compile when making changes in the Rig Graph.
Create new Controls, Bones, or Nulls by right-clicking in the Rig Hierarchy panel and selecting New > Control, Bone, or Null.

actor_editor_context.label: Actor Editor Context
actor_editor_context.description: Official documentation on Actor Editor Context (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Data Layers Outliner by selecting Window > World Partition > Data Layer Outliner.
Right-click the Data Layer you want to make current and select Make Current Data Layer(s).
Open the Outliner by selecting Window > Outliner and selecting one of the four Outliner instances.
Right-click the folder you want to make current, then select Make Current Folder from the context menu.
Click the Viewport Options button in the top-left corner of the Viewport, then select Advanced Settings.
Navigate to the Look and Feel section of the Level Editor - Viewports settings and clear the Show Actor Editor Context checkbox.

one_file_per_actor.label: One File Per Actor
one_file_per_actor.description: Official documentation on One File Per Actor (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Open the World Settings panel by going to Window > World Settings.
Navigate to the World section of the panel and click the checkbox next to Use External Actors.
Click Yes to convert all Actors to external packaging.
Save your Level.

procedural_content_generation_framework.label: Procedural Content Generation Framework
procedural_content_generation_framework.description: Official documentation on Procedural Content Generation Framework (part of the world_building subsystem).
keySteps: Build fast, iterative tools and content of any complexity ranging from asset utilities, such as buildings or biome generation, up to entire worlds.
Integrate PCG into existing world building pipelines.

paper_2d_overview.label: Paper 2D Overview

Enable the plugin.
Restart the editor.

building_packaging_and_publishing_projec.description: Official documentation on Building Packaging And Publishing Unreal Engine Projects For Ios Tvos And Ipados (part of the optimization subsystem).

rendering_features_for_mobile_games.description: Official documentation on Rendering Features For Mobile Games.
keySteps: Configure material settings for OpenGL ES 3.2 in Project Settings > Platforms > Android Material Quality - ES32.
Configure material settings for Metal 2.0 in Project Settings > Platforms > iOS Material Quality.

debugging_and_optimization_for_mobile.label: Debugging And Optimization For Mobile
debugging_and_optimization_for_mobile.description: Official documentation on Debugging And Optimization For Mobile. Covers advanced concepts and implementation details.

getting_started_with_xr_development.description: Official documentation on Getting Started With Xr Development. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the foundation subsystem).

build_operations_cooking_packaging_deplo.label: Build Operations Cooking Packaging Deploying And Running Projects
build_operations_cooking_packaging_deplo.description: Official documentation on Build Operations Cooking Packaging Deploying And Running Projects (part of the optimization subsystem).
keySteps: Use the Platforms button of the UE Toolbar to select a platform to package your project for.
From the drop-down menu under Platforms, build and launch a project on the available device you need.
Choose the target platform and adjust the Build Configuration for it (Development, Shipping, and so on).
Open Project Launcher by clicking Platforms > Project Launcher.
Add a Custom Launch Profile by clicking the Add button on the right side of the window.
Give the Custom Launch Profile a Name and Description.

packaging_and_cooking_games.label: Packaging And Cooking Games
packaging_and_cooking_games.description: Official documentation on Packaging And Cooking Games (part of the optimization subsystem).

cooking_content.label: Cooking Content
cooking_content.description: Official documentation on Cooking Content (part of the optimization subsystem).
keySteps: Use the Cook commandlet to cook data for your game.
Specify the commandlet via `-run=cook`.
Specify a platform to cook using `-targetplatform=<Plat1>+<Plat2>`.
Optionally, specify maps to build using `-Map=<Map1>+<Map2>+...`.

seeAlso.label: Build Operations Cooking Packaging Deploying and Running Projects

cooking_content_and_creating_chunks.label: Cooking Content And Creating Chunks
cooking_content_and_creating_chunks.description: Official documentation on Cooking Content And Creating Chunks (part of the optimization subsystem).
keySteps: Open your Project Settings and navigate to Game > Asset Manager to manually edit primary asset rules.
Designate the asset types that you want the asset manager to recognize as primary assets in the Primary Asset Types to Scan list.
Designate the Priority and Chunk ID of individual primary assets in the primary asset rules list.
Right-click inside the content browser, then click Miscellaneous > Data Asset to create a Primary Asset Label.
In the Pick Data Asset Class menu, select PrimaryAssetLabel and click Select.
Package your project to automatically create .pak files for each chunk, located in your project's Saved/StagedBuilds/[PlatformName]/[ProjectName]/Content/Paks folder.

using_the_autosdk_system.label: Using The Autosdk System
using_the_autosdk_system.description: Official documentation on Using The Autosdk System (part of the general subsystem).
keySteps: Start with an empty AutoSDK folder.
Copy files from the template directory as you add a particular SDK version.
Submit the AutoSDK folder to source control separately to the game or engine code.
Sync the AutoSDK folder and set the UE_SDKS_ROOT environment variable to point to the path on your local machine for UBT.

audio_memory_management.description: Official documentation on Audio Memory Management.

spatialization_and_sound_attenuation.description: Official documentation on Spatialization And Sound Attenuation (part of the audio subsystem).

subtitles_and_closed_captions_plugin.description: Official documentation on Subtitles And Closed Captions Plugin (part of the tools subsystem).

communicating_with_media_components_from.description: Official documentation on Communicating With Media Components From Unreal Engine (part of the gameplay subsystem).

the_media_plate_actor.label: The Media Plate Actor
the_media_plate_actor.description: Official documentation on The Media Plate Actor (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Drag a media file (video file or an image from a sequence) directly into the Viewport.
Drag a media source asset from your Content Drawer into the Viewport.
Use the Place Actors menu
Select the Media Plate actor in the Viewport.
In the Details panel, go to Media > Playlist.
Click the ellipsis (…) to select a media file and set the file path.

rendering_to_multiple_displays_with_ndis.label: Rendering To Multiple Displays With Ndisplay
rendering_to_multiple_displays_with_ndis.description: Official documentation on Rendering To Multiple Displays With Ndisplay.

introduction_to_performance_profiling_an.label: Introduction To Performance Profiling And Configuration
introduction_to_performance_profiling_an.description: Official documentation on Introduction To Performance Profiling And Configuration. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the optimization subsystem).
keySteps: Enable Show FPS in the viewport hamburger menu.
Click Stat > Engine in the viewport hamburger menu.
Enable FPS and Unit in the Stat > Engine menu.

seeAlso.label: Common Memory and CPU Performance Considerations

common_memory_and_cpu_performance_consid.label: Common Memory And Cpu Performance Considerations
common_memory_and_cpu_performance_consid.description: Official documentation on Common Memory And Cpu Performance Considerations (part of the optimization subsystem).
keySteps: Configure garbage collection in Project Settings > Engine > Garbage Collection.
Manually call the garbage collector using the Collect Garbage node in Blueprint, or the UObjectGlobals::CollectGarbage function in C++.
Create all the copies of an object that you need upfront, allocating them in memory, and then keeping them disabled or hidden until they are needed (object pooling).
Create a custom setter function to wrap around the operation to change the variable, then call another function or event that performs the needed logic only when you change that value.

seeAlso.label: Introduction to Performance Profiling and Configuration

stats_system_overview.label: Unreal Engine Stats System Overview
stats_system_overview.description: Official documentation on Unreal Engine Stats System Overview. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the foundation subsystem).
keySteps: Declare a stats group using DECLARE_STATS_GROUP, DECLARE_STATS_GROUP_VERBOSE, or DECLARE_STATS_GROUP_MAYBE_COMPILED_OUT.
Declare a stat using DECLARE_CYCLE_STAT, DECLARE_FLOAT_COUNTER_STAT, DECLARE_DWORD_COUNTER_STAT, DECLARE_FLOAT_ACCUMULATOR_STAT, DECLARE_DWORD_ACCUMULATOR_STAT, or DECLARE_MEMORY_STAT.
For stats accessible to the whole project, use the extern versions (e.g., DECLARE_CYCLE_STAT_EXTERN).
In the source file, define the extern stats using DEFINE_STAT(StatId).
Initialize memory stats with pools, typically in F*PlatformMemory::Init().
Set the memory stat using SET_MEMORY_STAT(StatId, PoolLimit).

seeAlso.label: Common Memory and CPU Performance Considerations

optimizing_rendering_with_pso_caches.label: Optimizing Rendering With Pso Caches
optimizing_rendering_with_pso_caches.description: Official documentation on Optimizing Rendering With Pso Caches.
keySteps: Play the game.
Log what is actually drawn.
Include this information in the build.

console_variables_editor.label: Console Variables Editor
console_variables_editor.description: Official documentation on Console Variables Editor (part of the blueprint subsystem).
keySteps: Enable the Console Variables Editor plugin in your project.
In the main menu, choose Window > Console Variables to open the Console Variables Editor.
Click (+) Add Console Variable and search for a command or variable in the input box.
Enter a console variable or command with a valid value to execute the command with that value and add the console variable to the list with its new value.
Hover over the right side of a row and click Remove to remove a console variable from the list.

umg_best_practices.description: Official documentation on Umg Best Practices (part of the ui subsystem).
keySteps: Have in mind the target resolution and build all your Widgets based off that resolution.
Author each of your Widget Blueprints using the target resolution setting inside UMG.
Create content inside of UMG at a DPI Scale of 1.0.
Wrap the Widget with a Scale Box instead of adjusting Scale through Render Transforms if you need to scale up the size of a Widget.

umg_editor_reference.label: Umg Editor Reference For Unreal Engine
umg_editor_reference.description: Official documentation covering umg editor reference (part of the ui subsystem).
