widget_type_reference_for_umg_ui_designe.description: Official documentation on Widget Type Reference For Umg Ui Designer.

how_to_use_unreal_insights_to_profile_an.label: How To Use Unreal Insights To Profile Android Games For Unreal Engine
how_to_use_unreal_insights_to_profile_an.description: Official documentation covering how to use unreal insights to profile android games (part of the optimization subsystem).
keySteps: Enable the AndroidFileServer plugin.
Enable the Use AndroidFileServer setting in Project Settings > Plugins > AndroidFileServer.
Package your UE project and push it to your Android device.
In your Unreal Engine install directory, open the Engine/Build/Android/UnrealGame folder.
Create an empty text file called UECommandline.txt.
Run UnrealAndroidFileTool.exe with the devices command to see a list of the devices attached to your computer.

mobile_rendering_and_shading_modes.label: Mobile Rendering And Shading Modes For Unreal Engine
mobile_rendering_and_shading_modes.description: Official documentation covering mobile rendering and shading modes.
keySteps: Set the mobile shading model in your Engine.ini file with the CVar r.Mobile.ShadingPath.
Use value 0 for Mobile Forward Shading.
Use value 1 for Mobile Deferred Shading.
Set the MobileUsesExtendedGBuffer parameter in your Engine.ini file to true to remove hardware limitations.

optimization_and_development_best_practi.label: Optimization And Development Best Practices For Mobile Projects
optimization_and_development_best_practi.description: Official documentation on Optimization And Development Best Practices For Mobile Projects. Covers advanced concepts and implementation details.
keySteps: Bake the normal map in xNormal as an 8k TIFF with 4xAA.
Import the TIFF into photoshop, then downres it to a 1k texture.
Apply a Gaussian Blur with a value of .35px.
Convert the image from 16-bit to 8-bit.
Export the image to a 24-bit TGA.
Import the final normal map into Unreal.

packaging_android_projects.label: Packaging Android Projects
packaging_android_projects.description: Official documentation on Packaging Android Projects (part of the optimization subsystem).
keySteps: Set up Android Studio on your computer (see Setting up Android SDK and NDK).
Enable Development Mode and USB Debugging on your Android device (see Setting Up Your Android Device For Development).
Configure your Project Settings for Android and accept the Android SDK license agreement (see the Android Quick Start Guide).
In the File menu, go to Package Project > Android and select the Texture format you want to package.
Double-click on the Install_[ProjectName]_Development.bat batch file to install the project on your Android device.
Enter ./Install_LinuxAndroidProject_Development-arm64.es2.sh into the terminal to install the project onto your Android device.

seeAlso.label: Building, Packaging, and Publishing Projects for iOS, tvOS, and iPadOS
Build Operations: Cooking, Packaging, Deploying, and Running Projects

packaging_ios_projects.label: Packaging Ios Projects
packaging_ios_projects.description: Official documentation on Packaging Ios Projects (part of the optimization subsystem).
keySteps: Connect your device to your computer.
Open your project in Unreal Editor.
In the File menu, select Package Project > iOS .
In the directory dialog, select a location for the .ipa file to be saved.
From Xcode go to Window and then select Devices and Simulators .
In the Devices section, press the Plus sign icon to start the app install process.

seeAlso.label: Building, Packaging, and Publishing Projects for iOS, tvOS, and iPadOS

using_lumen_global_illumination_on_mobil.label: Using Lumen Global Illumination On Mobile
using_lumen_global_illumination_on_mobil.description: Official documentation on Using Lumen Global Illumination On Mobile (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Enable the desktop renderer and SM5 support for mobile (see the Desktop Renderer section in Feature Levels and Rendering Modes for detailed instructions).
Enable Lumen as you would in a desktop application (see Lumen Global Illumination for detailed instructions).
Open your DeviceProfiles.ini file and add a MatchProfile line that specifies that devices meeting your criteria should use the SM5 profile of your choice.
In Android, enable both Vulkan and SM5 support in your DeviceProfiles.ini file.
Turn off r.Android.DisableVulkanSupport to enable Vulkan support.
Turn off r.Android.DisableVulkanSM5Support to enable Vulkan SM5 device profiles.

getting_started_in_niagara_effects.label: Getting Started In Niagara Effects For Unreal Engine
getting_started_in_niagara_effects.description: Official documentation covering getting started in niagara effects. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the vfx subsystem).

collisions_in_niagara.label: Collisions In Niagara For Unreal Engine
collisions_in_niagara.description: Official documentation covering collisions in niagara (part of the gameplay subsystem).

creating_custom_modules_in_niagara_effec.label: Creating Custom Modules In Niagara Effects For Unreal Engine
creating_custom_modules_in_niagara_effec.description: Official documentation covering creating custom modules in niagara effects. Covers advanced concepts and implementation details (part of the vfx subsystem).
keySteps: Use the Niagara Script Editor to define your own logic flow
Save your modules
Apply them in a Niagara stack
Refer to the Niagara Script Editor Reference page to understand how to use the Script Editor
Work with versioning enabled when iterating on new versions of modules

data_channels_in_niagara.label: Data Channels In Niagara For Unreal Engine
data_channels_in_niagara.description: Official documentation covering data channels in niagara (part of the vfx subsystem).

debugging_and_optimization_in_niagara_ef.label: Debugging And Optimization In Niagara Effects For Unreal Engine
debugging_and_optimization_in_niagara_ef.description: Official documentation covering debugging and optimization in niagara effects. Covers advanced concepts and implementation details (part of the vfx subsystem).
keySteps: Use the Niagara Debugger to turn on a heads-up display (HUD)
Output detailed information about the simulations in your level, such as the number of particles being generated, the amount of memory being used, and more
Capture a snapshot of information and then analyze that output
Create a new type of asset called a Niagara Effect Type to configure a variety of settings to help you manage budgeting in your level

niagara_fluids.label: Niagara Fluids
niagara_fluids.description: Official documentation on Niagara Fluids (part of the vfx subsystem).
keySteps: Read the Fluid Simulation Overview document.
Follow the Niagara Fluids Quick-Start Guide to learn how to add the templates to your project.
Create a Fluids emitter.
Bake the results out to a flipbook that you can use on any Material.

niagara_lightweight_emitters.label: Niagara Lightweight Emitters
niagara_lightweight_emitters.description: Official documentation on Niagara Lightweight Emitters (part of the lighting subsystem).
keySteps: Understand that Niagara lightweight emitters, also called stateless emitters, are optimized to minimize the use of tick during the simulation.

niagara_scratch_pad_modules.label: Niagara Scratch Pad Modules
niagara_scratch_pad_modules.description: Official documentation on Niagara Scratch Pad Modules (part of the vfx subsystem).
keySteps: In the Content Browser, right-click, then click Niagara System.
In the Template menu, select Minimal, and then click Create.
Name the new Niagara system (for example, NS_Minimal). Open the asset by double-clicking or pressing Enter.
On the Minimal emitter, click Add (+) next to the Particle Spawn header. Search for and select the New Scratch Pad Module option.
Rename your scratch module to something descriptive (for example, ApplyOffset).

reference_for_niagara_effects.label: Reference For Niagara Effects
reference_for_niagara_effects.description: Official documentation on Reference For Niagara Effects (part of the vfx subsystem).
keySteps: Understand the Niagara editor user interface.
Learn about the buttons on the UI, the panels available, and actions you can perform.
Familiarize yourself with key modules in systems and emitters in Niagara.
Use the script editor to modify existing modules or to create new modules.
Use the script editor to create new modules of your own.

tutorials_for_niagara_effects.label: Tutorials For Niagara Effects
tutorials_for_niagara_effects.description: Official documentation on Tutorials For Niagara Effects. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the vfx subsystem).
keySteps: Manually enable the Niagara plugin if you are not seeing the Niagara options.
Start with Level 1 Tutorials to learn the basics of Niagara.
Create Niagara systems to do simple environment effects like smoke.
Move to Level 2 Tutorials once you are familiar with the basics.
Learn how to use more than one emitter in a Niagara System.

anti_aliasing_and_upscaling.label: Anti Aliasing And Upscaling
anti_aliasing_and_upscaling.description: Official documentation on Anti Aliasing And Upscaling (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Project Settings from the main menu under Window.
In the Project Settings, anti-aliasing settings are found in the Engine > Rendering settings.
For Desktop / Console platforms, anti-aliasing settings are located under the Default Settings section.
For Mobile platforms, anti-aliasing settings are located under the Mobile section.

artists_tools_and_workflows_for_renderin.label: Artists Tools And Workflows For Rendering
artists_tools_and_workflows_for_renderin.description: Official documentation on Artists Tools And Workflows For Rendering.

creating_a_new_global_shader_as_a_plugin.label: Creating A New Global Shader As A Plugin
creating_a_new_global_shader_as_a_plugin.description: Official documentation on Creating A New Global Shader As A Plugin (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: Create a new Games project and select a Blank template with Maximum Quality and No Starter Content enabled.
Right-click on the project in Visual Studio and select the Build option to compile the project.
Open the Plugins manager by going to Edit > Plugins and then click on the New Plugin option.
Select the Blank plugin, input the name Foo, and press the Create Plugin button.
Shut down Unreal Engine and Visual Studio, then go to the Plugins > Foo plugin folder inside your project folder.
Inside the Foo plugins folder, add a new folder called Shaders, then inside of that folder, create a new folder called Private.

environmental_light_with_fog_clouds_sky_.label: Environmental Light With Fog Clouds Sky And Atmosphere
environmental_light_with_fog_clouds_sky_.description: Official documentation on Environmental Light With Fog Clouds Sky And Atmosphere (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Add Directional Lights for the sun and moon.
Add a single Sky Light with optional real-time capturing.
Add a Sky Atmosphere with its own height fog.
Add Volumetric Clouds with or without a sky dome mesh.
Enable Real Time Capture on the Sky Light.

Use the keyboard shortcut Right Ctrl + L (first Directional Light) or Right Ctrl + Right Shift + L (second Directional Light) in combination with moving the mouse to change lighting dynamically and see the results instantly.

general_features_of_rendering.label: General Features Of Rendering
general_features_of_rendering.description: Official documentation on General Features Of Rendering.

global_illumination.label: Global Illumination
global_illumination.description: Official documentation on Global Illumination (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Set up a Lightmap UV to store lighting data for Static Meshes when using precomputed lighting.
Use CPU-based Lightmass with Unreal Swarm to compute and generate lighting data on a single machine or distribute it to build farms.
Use GPU-based Lightmass with an NVIDIA GPU supporting DirectX 12 and ray tracing to compute and generate lighting data.
Use Lumen for a fully dynamic global illumination and reflection system, designed for next-generation consoles.
Use Screen Space Global Illumination (SSGI) as a post-processing effect in conjunction with existing precomputed or dynamic global illumination methods as an additive effect.

graphics_programming_overview.label: Graphics Programming Overview For Unreal Engine
graphics_programming_overview.description: Official documentation covering graphics programming overview. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the foundation subsystem).
keySteps: Start reading the code at FDeferredShadingSceneRenderer::Render to understand how a new frame is rendered on the rendering thread.
Use the profilegpu command and look through the draw events.
Use Find in Files in Visual Studio on the draw event name to find the corresponding C++ implementation.
Use stat unit to show overall frame time as well as the game thread, rendering thread, and GPU times to identify bottlenecks.
Use show x to toggle specified show flags. Use show to get the list of showflags and their current state.

landscape_materials.label: Landscape Materials
keySteps: In the Material Editor, add a LandscapeLayerBlend node.
In the Details panel, next to Layers, click the plus icon ( + ) to add a layer.
Expand the layer to view its properties.
Change the Layer Name to a descriptive name for the layer, for example, Snow.
Determine whether you want the layer to be alpha blended or height blended, and set the Blend Type accordingly.
Connect the LandscapeLayerBlend node's output to the Base Color input of your material's base node.

large_world_coordinates_rendering_5.label: Large World Coordinates Rendering 5
large_world_coordinates_rendering_5.description: Official documentation covering large world coordinates rendering.
keySteps: Change View to PrimaryView when accessing values/matrices in the world space (LocalToWorld, PreViewTranslation).
Use the LWCHackToFloat function where needed if your code performing in world space doesn’t compile (for example, it is missing function overloads or type conversions).
Consider changing the shader code to operate in TranslatedWorldSpace instead of WorldSpace if your code still does not compile.
Use LWC types (FLWSVector3 instead of float3) and corresponding LWC functions for world space values.

seeAlso.label: Artists Tools and Workflows for Rendering

lumen_technical_details.label: Lumen Technical Details
lumen_technical_details.description: Official documentation on Lumen Technical Details (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Visualize Cards with the console command r.Lumen.Visualize.CardPlacement 1.
Adjust the number of Cards by setting Max Lumen Mesh Cards in the Build Settings of the Static Mesh Editor.
Use the Ray Tracing Quality Switch node to provide a version of the Material that works with Lumen Surface Cache, or to optimize Surface Cache captures for complex materials.
Disable Screen Traces from the Level Viewport's Show > Lumen menu and removing the check next to Screen Traces.
Disable the setting for Screen Traces in the Post Process Volume under Lumen Global Illumination and Lumen Reflections categories.
Use the command r.DistanceFields.LogAtlasStats 1 to output mesh distance field statistics to the log.

optimizing_and_debugging_projects_for_re.label: Optimizing And Debugging Projects For Realtime Rendering
optimizing_and_debugging_projects_for_re.description: Official documentation on Optimizing And Debugging Projects For Realtime Rendering.
keySteps: Improve content creation workflows.
Perform profiling captures to know where time is being spent to render each frame.
Use built-in editor tools.
Adjust built-in systems to fit your project's needs more closely.

overview_of_shaders_in_plugins_unreal_en.label: Overview Of Shaders In Plugins Unreal Engine
overview_of_shaders_in_plugins_unreal_en.description: Official documentation on Overview Of Shaders In Plugins Unreal Engine. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: Use the Plugin Wizard to quickly create all of the needed files and folders for your Plugin.
Add all of your files and folder in the required location and then regenerate your Visual Studio solution files.
In your ProjectName.uplugin, make sure that the module's LoadingPhase to PostConfigInit (only for the modules that will have shader implementations).
Enqueue FIFO (first in, first out) commands through the ENQUEUE_RENDER_COMMAND to the rendering thread.
Add asserts such as check (IsInGameThread()); or check (IsInRenderingThread()); for improved threading robustness.

parallel_rendering_overview.label: Parallel Rendering Overview For Unreal Engine
parallel_rendering_overview.description: Official documentation covering parallel rendering overview. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system.
keySteps: Set r.rhicmdusedeferredcontexts to 0 to disable parallelization of the backend.
Set r.rhicmduseparallelalgorithms to 0 to disable parallelization of the frontend.
Set r.rhithread.enable to 0 to disable the RHI Thread completely.
Set r.rhicmdbypass to 1 to completely disable command list generation and make the renderer behave like it originally did.

physically_based_materials.label: Physically Based Materials
physically_based_materials.description: Official documentation on Physically Based Materials.
keySteps: Set the Metallic value to 0 for nonmetals.
Set the Metallic value to 1 for metals.
Use a high Roughness value to make very diffuse Materials.
Use a black and white mask passed into the Metallic input when metals and nonmetals are present in the same Material.

ray_tracing_and_path_tracing_features.label: Ray Tracing And Path Tracing Features
ray_tracing_and_path_tracing_features.description: Official documentation on Ray Tracing And Path Tracing Features (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Verify your Windows build by typing winver in the Windows search bar.
Use NVIDIA RTX and some GTX series cards with DXR support using the latest device drivers.
Use Unreal Engine Version 5.0 and Later
Use Deferred Path

rendering_components.label: Rendering Components
keySteps: Add an AtmosphericFogComponent to create fogging effects like clouds or ambient fog.
Adjust the Decay Height setting of the AtmosphericFogComponent to control fog density.
Add an ExponentialHeightFogComponent to create fog effects with density related to height.
Use a BillboardComponent for a 2D Texture that always faces the camera for placement and selection.
Add a DecalComponent to render a material onto the surface of a mesh.

rendering_high_quality_frames_with_movie.label: Rendering High Quality Frames With Movie Render Queue
rendering_high_quality_frames_with_movie.description: Official documentation on Rendering High Quality Frames With Movie Render Queue.
keySteps: Launch the Registry Editor by searching for regedit in the Windows Start menu search bar.
Navigate to Computer\HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\GraphicsDrivers.
Select TdrDelay, then right-click and select Modify.
Select Decimal, set a Value data of 60, then click OK.
Go to Edit > Plugins, search for movie, and enable the Movie Render Pipeline plugin.

shaders_in_plugins.label: Shaders In Plugins For Unreal Engine
shaders_in_plugins.description: Official documentation on Shaders In Plugins For Unreal Engine (part of the materials subsystem).

skeletal_mesh_rendering_paths.label: Skeletal Mesh Rendering Paths
skeletal_mesh_rendering_paths.description: Official documentation on Skeletal Mesh Rendering Paths.
keySteps: In Project Settings under Engine > Rendering > Skinning, check the box for Support 16-bit Bone Index to support more bones per section.
Restart the editor for the change to take effect.
Re-import Skeletal Meshes already in your project before this change for them to be updated.
Enable Unlimited Bone Influence mode from the Project Settings under the Engine > Rendering > Skinning section.
Enable Unlimited Bone Influences and set the Unlimited Bone Influences Threshold to 8.

sun_and_sky_actor.label: Sun And Sky Actor
sun_and_sky_actor.description: Official documentation on Sun And Sky Actor (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Choose Edit > Plugins from the main menu.
Find the Sun Position Calculator plugin under the Misc category and check it's Enabled checkbox.
Click the Restart Now button to apply your changes and re-open the Unreal Editor.
Drag the Sun and Sky Actor from the Editor Place Actors panel in the Lights tab into the Level viewport.
Remove any existing Directional Light, Sky Light, or SkyAtmosphere components from the scene.

supported_features_by_rendering_path_for.label: Supported Features By Rendering Path For Desktop With Unreal Engine
supported_features_by_rendering_path_for.description: Official documentation on Supported Features By Rendering Path For Desktop With Unreal Engine.
keySteps: Use Post Processing to control the overall look and feel of your scene using placed volumes.
Use the Lens category to affect the look of the scene that can be created by a camera lens.
Use the Color Grading category to enable color styling and color palettes to be applied on top of the rendered scene.
Use the Film category to enable artistic choices to map the scene colors to match those of the Academy Color Encoding System (or ACES) standard.

seeAlso.label: Artists Tools and Workflows for Rendering

temporal_super_resolution.label: Temporal Super Resolution
temporal_super_resolution.description: Official documentation on Temporal Super Resolution (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Toggle the TSR stats on and off using the console command stat tsr.
Use the TSR frame rate statistics to help identify what may affect TSR's accumulation to the overall image.
Set the checkbox next to TSR in the Viewport Options menu under Stat > Engine.
Check the box next to GPU in the Viewport Options menu under Stat > Advanced.
Override the Screen Percentage, in the Viewport Options menu, to see the difference in performance when rendering at 100 versus 50 percent.

third_party_rendering_tools_and_plugins.label: Third Party Rendering Tools And Plugins
third_party_rendering_tools_and_plugins.description: Official documentation on Third Party Rendering Tools And Plugins.
keySteps: Utilize integrated third-party tools for debugging.
Use integrated third-party tools for gathering additional information.
Take advantage of third-party tools that offer hardware benefits, like support for multiple linked GPUs.

threaded_rendering.label: Threaded Rendering
keySteps: Understand the interactions of the game thread and rendering thread.
Use mechanisms to ensure determinism.
Have data in separate structures that are 'owned' by the different threads.
Communicate between threads using the ENQUEUE_UNIQUE_RENDER_COMMAND_XXXPARAMETER macro.
Use FRenderCommandFence to track the progress of the rendering thread on the game thread.
Call FlushRenderingCommands to block the game thread until the rendering thread has caught up.

uv_editor.label: Uv Editor
uv_editor.description: Official documentation on Uv Editor (part of the tools subsystem).
keySteps: Access the UV Editor from the UV category in Modeling Mode.
Access the UV Editor by right-clicking your mesh within your Level.
Access the UV Editor by right-clicking your mesh in the Content Browser.
Use the Channel tool to create and edit UV maps.
Use the AutoUV tool, then the remaining tools to work out the details.
Use the Seam tool for a manual start.

datasmith_plugins.label: Datasmith Plugins For Unreal Engine
datasmith_plugins.description: Official documentation on Datasmith Plugins For Unreal Engine (part of the tools subsystem).
keySteps: Import Datasmith Content into Unreal Engine
Use Datasmith to bring files that you create in supported 3D design applications into Unreal Engine
Customize the Datasmith Import Process
Import Datasmith and CAD files using Blueprint or Python

lidar_point_cloud_plugin.label: Lidar Point Cloud Plugin For Unreal Engine
lidar_point_cloud_plugin.description: Official documentation covering lidar point cloud plugin (part of the tools subsystem).

modeling_and_geometry_scripting.label: Modeling And Geometry Scripting
modeling_and_geometry_scripting.description: Official documentation on Modeling And Geometry Scripting (part of the tools subsystem).

actors.label: Actors
actors.description: Official documentation on Actors (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Create new instances of AActor classes by spawning them using the generic SpawnActor() function or one of its specialized templated versions.
Associate Components with their containing Actor when they are created.
Designate which Component acts as the root for the Actor using the RootComponent property.
Update Actors each frame using the Tick() function.
Explicitly destroy Actors by calling Destroy() to remove them from the level.

components.label: Components
components.description: Official documentation on Components (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Enable ticking by setting PrimaryComponentTick.bCanEverTick to true in its constructor.
Call PrimaryComponentTick.SetTickFunctionEnable(true) to turn updates on.
Deactivate ticking by calling PrimaryComponentTick.SetTickFunctionEnable(false).
Mark render data as dirty with the MarkRenderStateDirty function.
Call SetIsVisualizationComponent on a regular Component to make it a Visualization Component.

pawns.label: Pawns
pawns.description: Official documentation on Pawns (part of the gameplay subsystem).

player_controllers.label: Player Controllers
player_controllers.description: Official documentation on Player Controllers (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Consider what functionality should be in the PlayerController versus the Pawn.
Handle input in the Pawn for less complex cases.
Handle input in the PlayerController for complex needs like multiple players or dynamic character changes.
Put persistent functionality like scorekeeping in the PlayerController.

game_mode_and_game_state.label: Game Mode And Game State
game_mode_and_game_state.description: Official documentation on Game Mode And Game State (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Create a subclass of AGameModeBase for each match format, mission type, or special zone.
Override common functions like InitGame, PreLogin, PostLogin, HandleStartingNewPlayer, RestartPlayer, SpawnDefaultPawnAtTransform, and Logout in your Game Mode subclass.
Create Blueprints derived from Game Mode classes to set defaults like Default Pawn Class, HUD Class, Player Controllers Class, and Spectator Class.
Use GetMatchState to query the current state, or wrappers like HasMatchStarted, IsMatchInProgress, and HasMatchEnded.

animation_sequences.label: Animation Sequences
keySteps: Select **Import** in the **Content Browser**.
Navigate in your computer's File Explorer window and select the FBX file containing an animation you want to import.
Ensure the **Import Animation** option is enabled.
Select **Import** or **Import All**.

animation_retargeting.label: Animation Retargeting
keySteps: Right-click on your root bone and Recursively Set Translation Retargeting Skeleton so all bones are set to Skeleton.
Find the Pelvis or equivalent bone and set that to AnimationScaled.
Find the Root bone, any IK bones, any weapon bones, or other marker-style bones and set them to use Animation.
Assign a Rig inside the Skeleton Editor under the Retarget Manager to process animation data from one Skeleton to another.
Assign the same Rig to both Skeleton assets.

animation_state_machines.label: Animation State Machines
animation_state_machines.description: Official documentation on Animation State Machines.

animation_curves.label: Animation Curves
keySteps: View an Animation Sequence in the Animation Sequence Editor, click the Curves track dropdown menu and select Add Curve… > Create Curve.
Type in the name of the new curve and press Enter to create it.
Select the Curve dropdown menu on the Animation Curve track and click Edit Curve to open the Curve Editor.
Create keyframes by pressing Enter in the Curve Editor.
Enable Window > Anim Curves to view the Anim Curves panel from the Skeleton Editor, Animation Sequence Editor, or Animation Blueprints Editor.

animation_notifies.label: Animation Notifies
keySteps: Open an Animation Sequence Asset and locate the Notifies track in the timeline.
Click Add Track (+) > Add Notify Track on the Notifies track to add notify tracks.
Right-click in the Notify track's timeline region to view available Animation Notify types.
Select an Animation Notify type to create the Notify keyframe at your cursor position.
Drag Notify keyframes in the timeline to edit them.

material_functions.label: Material Functions
material_functions.description: Official documentation on Material Functions (part of the materials subsystem).

material_parameter_collections.label: Material Parameter Collections
material_parameter_collections.description: Official documentation on Material Parameter Collections (part of the materials subsystem).

material_attributes.description: Official documentation on Material Attributes (part of the materials subsystem).

physically_based_rendering.description: Official documentation on Physically Based Rendering.

volumetric_fog.label: Volumetric Fog
volumetric_fog.description: Official documentation on Volumetric Fog (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Adjust properties in your Exponential Height Fog component under the Volumetric Fog section.
Control how much a light contributes to the Volumetric Fog by adjusting the Volumetric Scattering Intensity on each Light's Details panel under the Light section.
Toggle whether or not to cast a volumetric shadow for lights contributing to Volumetric Fog using the Cast Volumetric Shadow property.
Create Volume Materials using the Volume domain to describe Albedo, Emissive, and Extinction for a given point in space.
Use the console command profilegpu to inspect the cost of particles using Volume domain.

exponential_height_fog.label: Exponential Height Fog
exponential_height_fog.description: Official documentation on Exponential Height Fog (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: In the Place Actors panel, select the Exponential Height Fog Actor, under Visual Effects.
Left-click and drag to place it in the world.
Position the Exponential Height Fog Actor to determine the height of the fog.
Use the Fog Height Falloff to further adjust the height.
Enable Volumetric Fog in the Exponential Height Fog's Details panel under the Volumetric Fog category.

collision_responses.label: Collision Responses
collision_responses.description: Official documentation on Collision Responses (part of the gameplay subsystem).

physics_bodies.label: Physics Bodies
physics_bodies.description: Official documentation on Physics Bodies (part of the gameplay subsystem).

camera_components.description: Official documentation on Camera Components (part of the gameplay subsystem).

camera_animation.label: Camera Animation
keySteps: Create a blank CameraAnim asset via the Content Browser.
Convert a camera track in another Matinee to a CameraAnim by choosing "Export to CameraAnim" in the right-click menu on the camera interp group.
Edit a CameraAnim by double-clicking the asset in the Content Browser.
Manipulate the temporary camera placed in the world to create keys and preview your animation.

networking_overview.label: Networking Overview
networking_overview.description: Official documentation on Networking Overview. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system.

replication.label: Replication
replication.description: Official documentation on Replication (part of the networking subsystem).

dedicated_servers.label: Dedicated Servers
dedicated_servers.description: Official documentation on Dedicated Servers (part of the networking subsystem).

python_scripting.label: Python Scripting
python_scripting.description: Official documentation on Python Scripting (part of the tools subsystem).

landscape_splines.label: Landscape Splines
landscape_splines.description: Official documentation on Landscape Splines (part of the world_building subsystem).
keySteps: Under the Manage tab, select Splines.
Press Ctrl + Left-click to set your spline's first control point.
Press Ctrl + Left-click again to create another control point and connect it to the first point by a spline segment.
In the Content Browser, find and select the Static Mesh asset that you want to use with your spline.
Click on a spline control point on your Landscape.
In the Level Editor's Details panel, in the Landscape Spline section, next to Select all connected, click the Segments button.

landscape_sculpting.label: Landscape Sculpting
landscape_sculpting.description: Official documentation on Landscape Sculpting (part of the world_building subsystem).

landscape_painting.label: Landscape Painting
landscape_painting.description: Official documentation on Landscape Painting (part of the world_building subsystem).

procedural_foliage_tool.label: Procedural Foliage Tool
procedural_foliage_tool.description: Official documentation on Procedural Foliage Tool (part of the world_building subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Edit menu then click on Editor Preferences.
Enable the Procedural Foliage option by clicking on the checkmark box next to the word Procedural Foliage.
Create a new Procedural Foliage Spawner by right-clicking in the Content Browser, expanding the Foliage section, and then clicking on the Procedural Foliage Spawner.
Drag the Procedural Foliage Spawner from the Content Browser into the level and position it so that it is in the center of the level or at 0,0,200 in the X, Y, and Z axis.
Create a new Static Mesh Foliage by right - clicking in the Content Browser expanding the Foliage section and then click on Static Mesh Foliage.
Add a new item to the Foliage Types array by clicking the Plus Sign icon that is to the right of the Foliage Types menu option.

plugins.label: Plugins
plugins.description: Official documentation on Plugins (part of the tools subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Plugin editing interface from the Edit menu.
Browse categories of Plugins using the tree interface on the left.
Search Plugins displayed in the list by name using the search control at the top.
Enable or disable a Plugin for use with your active project by toggling the Enabled check box under the Plugin's description.
Restart the Editor for the change to take effect.

creating_plugins.label: Creating Plugins
creating_plugins.description: Official documentation on Creating Plugins (part of the tools subsystem).

plugin_system.description: Official documentation on Plugin System (part of the tools subsystem).

metahuman_creator.label: Metahuman Creator
metahuman_creator.description: Official documentation on Metahuman Creator (part of the animation subsystem).

metahuman_animator.label: Metahuman Animator
metahuman_animator.description: Official documentation on Metahuman Animator (part of the animation subsystem).

metahuman_identity.label: Metahuman Identity
metahuman_identity.description: Official documentation on Metahuman Identity (part of the animation subsystem).

procedural_mesh_component.label: Procedural Mesh Component
procedural_mesh_component.description: Official documentation on Procedural Mesh Component (part of the gameplay subsystem).

sound_cues.label: Sound Cues
sound_cues.description: Official documentation on Sound Cues (part of the audio subsystem).

sound_classes.label: Sound Classes
sound_classes.description: Official documentation on Sound Classes (part of the audio subsystem).
keySteps: Right-click from the Content Browser, then select Audio > Classes > Sound Class to set up a new Sound Class.
Double-click the Sound Class in the Content Browser to open the Details panel.
Click the plus (+) icon in line with Child Classes and select it from the dropdown to add a Child Class.
Drag the Sound Class onto the graph and connect the Children output pin from the Parent Class node to the input pin of the Child Class node to add a Child Class.

attenuation.label: Attenuation
attenuation.description: Official documentation on Attenuation (part of the audio subsystem).

sound_concurrency.label: Sound Concurrency
sound_concurrency.description: Official documentation on Sound Concurrency (part of the audio subsystem).

gpu_profiling.label: Gpu Profiling
gpu_profiling.description: Official documentation on Gpu Profiling. Covers advanced concepts and implementation details (part of the optimization subsystem).

cpu_profiling.label: Cpu Profiling
cpu_profiling.description: Official documentation on Cpu Profiling. Covers advanced concepts and implementation details (part of the optimization subsystem).

memory_profiling.label: Memory Profiling
memory_profiling.description: Official documentation on Memory Profiling. Covers advanced concepts and implementation details (part of the optimization subsystem).

draw_call_optimization.label: Draw Call Optimization
draw_call_optimization.description: Official documentation on Draw Call Optimization. Covers advanced concepts and implementation details.

gameplay_ability_system.label: Gameplay Ability System
gameplay_ability_system.description: The Gameplay Ability System (GAS) is a flexible framework for implementing abilities, attributes, effects, and gameplay tags.

ai_perception.label: Ai Perception
keySteps: Add the AI Perception Component to your AIController Blueprint from the Components window.
Access the AI Perception Component's properties inside the Details panel.
Add the type of Senses to perceive under the AI Perception and Senses Config section.
Adjust the properties for each Sense to define how the Sense is perceived.

behavior_tree_decorators.label: Behavior Tree Decorators
behavior_tree_decorators.description: Official documentation on Behavior Tree Decorators (part of the ai subsystem).

behavior_tree_services.label: Behavior Tree Services
behavior_tree_services.description: Official documentation on Behavior Tree Services (part of the ai subsystem).

behavior_tree_tasks.label: Behavior Tree Tasks
behavior_tree_tasks.description: Official documentation on Behavior Tree Tasks (part of the ai subsystem).

particle_systems_cascade.label: Particle Systems Cascade
particle_systems_cascade.description: Official documentation on Particle Systems Cascade (part of the vfx subsystem).

screen_space_reflections.label: Screen Space Reflections
screen_space_reflections.description: Official documentation on Screen Space Reflections (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Enable/Fade/Disable the Screen Space Reflection feature by percentage (avoid numbers between 0 and 1 for consistency).
Set Quality to 0 for Lowest Quality or 100 for Maximum Quality (50 is the default to provide better performance).
Set Max Roughness to determine what roughness we fade the Screen Space Reflections (0.8 works well, smaller can run faster).

sequencer_scripting.label: Sequencer Scripting
sequencer_scripting.description: Official documentation on Sequencer Scripting (part of the cinematics subsystem).

sequencer_tracks.label: Sequencer Tracks
sequencer_tracks.description: Official documentation on Sequencer Tracks (part of the cinematics subsystem).

reflection_system.label: Reflection System
reflection_system.description: Official documentation on Reflection System (part of the general subsystem).
keySteps: Use the UCLASS macro to tag classes derived from UObject.
Define structs using the USTRUCT() macro.
Use UFUNCTION and UPROPERTY macros to make UE aware of new classes, functions, and variables.

gameplay_camera_system.label: Gameplay Camera System
gameplay_camera_system.description: Official documentation on Gameplay Camera System.

gameplay_targeting_system.label: Gameplay Targeting System
gameplay_targeting_system.description: Official documentation on Gameplay Targeting System.
keySteps: Enable the Targeting System from the Editor by navigating to Edit > Plugins > Gameplay > Gameplay Abilities > Targeting System
Create a Targeting Preset, which is a data asset that defines a set of Targeting Tasks.
Define reusable targeting tasks and presets that set up how the tasks behave without defining a UAsset for each one.
Call the UTargetingSubsystem::ExecuteTargetingRequest function to perform Immediate Targeting Requests.
Call the UTargetingSubsystem::StartAsyncTargetingRequest function to perform Async Targeting Requests.

user_interfaces_and_huds.label: User Interfaces And Huds
user_interfaces_and_huds.description: Official documentation on User Interfaces And Huds (part of the ui subsystem).

class_creation_basics.label: Class Creation Basics
class_creation_basics.description: Official documentation on Class Creation Basics. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system (part of the general subsystem).

cloth_simulation.label: Cloth Simulation
cloth_simulation.description: Official documentation on Cloth Simulation (part of the general subsystem).

hair_physics.label: Hair Physics
hair_physics.description: Official documentation on Hair Physics (part of the gameplay subsystem).

online_subsystems_and_services.label: Online Subsystems And Services
online_subsystems_and_services.description: Official documentation on Online Subsystems And Services (part of the networking subsystem).

essential_material_concepts.label: Essential Unreal Engine Material Concepts
essential_material_concepts.description: Official documentation on Essential Unreal Engine Material Concepts (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: Right-click in the Content Browser.
Select Material in the Create Basic Asset section of the context menu.
Give the Material a unique and descriptive name.
Double-click the Material asset to begin editing the Material.
Configure the Material Domain, Blend Mode, and Shading Model properties first.

material_editor_ui.label: Unreal Engine Material Editor Ui
material_editor_ui.description: Official documentation on Unreal Engine Material Editor Ui (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: Open Asset - Opens the Global Asset Picker to quickly find an asset and open the appropriate editor.
Find in Content Browser - Locates and selects the current asset in the Content Browser.
Reset Layout - Resets your layout to a default arrangement.
Save Layout - Saves the current layout of the panels as the new default layout.

material_analyzer_tool.label: Unreal Engine Material Analyzer Tool
material_analyzer_tool.description: Official documentation on Unreal Engine Material Analyzer Tool (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: In the menu bar, click Tools > Audit > Material Analyzer.
Click the dropdown menu next to Material to Analyze.
Select the Material or Material instance you want to analyze using the list or search bar.
Click the arrow next to each line in the suggestion list to see the specific instances identified.
Click the Create Local Collection button to place all the related instances into a local collection.
Click the arrow next to the Static Switch Parameters column to display the full list.

material_expressions_reference.label: Unreal Engine Material Expressions Reference
material_expressions_reference.description: Official documentation on Unreal Engine Material Expressions Reference (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: Assign all parameters a unique name using the Parameter Name details property.
Edit an instance in the Material Instance Editor.
Set a default value for your parameters in the Details Panel.
Enter text into the Desc (Description) property in the Details Panel.

material_functions_reference.label: Unreal Engine Material Functions Reference
material_functions_reference.description: Official documentation on Unreal Engine Material Functions Reference (part of the materials subsystem).

material_instance_editor_ui.label: Unreal Engine Material Instance Editor Ui
material_instance_editor_ui.description: Official documentation on Unreal Engine Material Instance Editor Ui (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: Double-click a Material Instance asset in the Content Browser to open the Material Instance Editor.
Right-click the Material Instance thumbnail in the Content Browser and choose Edit from the context menu.
Place a check in the box to the left of the parameter name in the Details panel.
Type a new value into the field or use the color picker to set a new value.
Save your Material instance when you are finished editing parameters.

material_properties.label: Unreal Engine Material Properties
material_properties.description: Official documentation on Unreal Engine Material Properties (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: Set the Material Domain to Surface for use on object surfaces.
Set the Material Domain to Deferred Decal when making a Decal Material.
Set the Material Domain to Light Function when creating a Material for use with a Light Function.
Select the desired Blend Mode to control how the Material blends with the background.
Choose the appropriate Shading Model to determine how Material inputs are combined to make the final color.
Enable Two Sided to flip the normal on back faces, calculating lighting for both front and back faces.

materials_tutorials.label: Unreal Engine Materials Tutorials
materials_tutorials.description: Official documentation on Unreal Engine Materials Tutorials. Suitable for beginners getting started with this system.

material_data_types.label: Material Data Types
material_data_types.description: Official documentation on Material Data Types (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: Use a Constant Material Expression node to store a single constant float value.
Use a Scalar Parameter to store a float that can be modified in a Material Instance after the Material is compiled.
Use the Constant2Vector Material Expression to define a float2 for attributes like UV or XY coordinates, or Scale.
Use a Constant3Vector node to define a float3, commonly used for defining a solid color or (x, y, z) coordinates.
Parameterize a Constant3Vector by right-clicking it and choosing Convert to Parameter from the context menu to create a Vector Parameter (float4).

layering_materials.label: Layering Materials
keySteps: Define each Material type you wish to use as a layer within its own Material Function using the Material Attributes expressions.
Create a base Material which contains all the logic needed to blend between your various layers.
Use the Layer Parameters tab in the Material Instance Editor to edit layered Materials.
Swap layers in and out of a Material Instance.
Change the order of the layer stack.
Modify the way layers are blended without editing the node graph in the base Material.

substrate_materials.label: Substrate Materials
keySteps: Learn to use this Beta feature, but use caution when shipping with it.

storing_custom_data_materials_per_primit.label: Storing Custom Data Materials Per Primitive
storing_custom_data_materials_per_primit.description: Official documentation on Storing Custom Data Materials Per Primitive. Covers advanced concepts and implementation details.
keySteps: Create Scalar and Vector Material Parameters to control parts of your Material logic.
Enable Use Custom Primitive Data on each parameter you want to set and control dynamically.
Give each parameter with Custom Primitive Data enabled a unique Primitive Data Index in the Details Panel.
Use the Set Custom Primitive Data nodes in Blueprint to set and control the Material Parameters for the values stored in the custom data array.
Select the Static Mesh Component in the Details panel and expand the Custom Primitive Data Defaults section to setup Custom Primitive Data Default values for an Actor.
Use the Plus (+) icon to add elements to the array.

customized_uvs_materials.label: Customized Uvs Materials
customized_uvs_materials.description: Official documentation covering customized uvs. Covers advanced concepts and implementation details (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: In the Material Editor, select the main material node.
Edit the Num Customized UVs property in the Material category.
Set Num Customized UVs to a number greater than 0.
CustomizedUVs pins will show on the main material node.

curve_atlases_materials.label: Curve Atlases Materials
curve_atlases_materials.description: Official documentation covering curve atlases (part of the materials subsystem).
keySteps: Right-click in the Content Browser, and select Miscellaneous > Curve to create a new Curve Asset.
In the Pick Curve Class dialog, select CurveLinearColor.
Right-click in the Content Browser and select Miscellaneous > Curve Atlas to create a new Curve Atlas.
Create a new Material and in the graph, right-click and add a Curve Atlas Row Parameter node.
Select the Curve Atlas Row Parameter expression to display its Details Panel properties and assign the Atlas and select a Curve from that atlas to use with this Material by default.

sequencer_cinematic_editor_unreal_engine.label: Sequencer Cinematic Editor Unreal Engine
sequencer_cinematic_editor_unreal_engine.description: Official documentation on Sequencer Cinematic Editor Unreal Engine (part of the cinematics subsystem).
keySteps: Create a new Cine Camera Actor using the Create Camera button in the Toolbar.
Locate the current sequence's Level Sequence asset in the Content Browser using the Find in Content Browser button.
Open the Curve Editor for fine tuning of animation keyframes and tangents.
Use the Range Slider at the bottom of the timeline to pan and zoom the Timeline view horizontally.

cinematic_editor_and_project_settings.label: Cinematic Editor And Project Settings
cinematic_editor_and_project_settings.description: Official documentation on Cinematic Editor And Project Settings (part of the cinematics subsystem).
keySteps: Navigate to Edit > Editor Preferences… in Unreal Engine's top menu bar.
Select Level Sequence Editor in the sidebar in the Content Editors category.
Modify preferences for Embedded Actor Sequence Editor, Niagara Sequence Editor, Take Recorder Sequence Editor, Template Sequence Editor, or UMG Sequence Editor under Content Editors.
Adjust settings like Auto Change Mode, Allow Edits Mode, Key Group Mode, and Key Interpolation to customize Sequencer behavior.

cinematic_workflow_tips_for_sequencer.label: Cinematic Workflow Tips For Sequencer
cinematic_workflow_tips_for_sequencer.description: Official documentation on Cinematic Workflow Tips For Sequencer (part of the cinematics subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Editor Preferences window and locate Cycle Between Translate, Rotate, and Scale under General > Keyboard Shortcuts.
Unbind this shortcut by clicking Remove this binding (X).
From the Viewport's Perspective menu, enable Cinematic Viewport.
Hold Ctrl will add the new actor to Sequencer as a possessable.
Hold Shift will add the new actor to Sequencer as a spawnable.

sequencer_track_list.label: Sequencer Track List
sequencer_track_list.description: Official documentation on Sequencer Track List (part of the cinematics subsystem).
keySteps: Click Add Track (+) in Sequencer's Outliner to reveal the list of tracks.
Right-click in the empty region of the outliner to bring up the track list.
Triple-click on the track text, right-click and select Rename, or press F2 to rename a track.
Right-click a track and select Locked to lock that track.
Right-click a track and select Pinned to pin that track.
Right-click a track and select Mute to mute that track.

sequencer_hotkeys.label: Sequencer Hotkeys
sequencer_hotkeys.description: Official documentation on Sequencer Hotkeys (part of the cinematics subsystem).
keySteps: Press Spacebar to toggle playback of the sequence between play and pause.
Press Left Arrow to step backward in the sequence by a single frame.
Press Right Arrow to step forward in the sequence by a single frame.
Press Ctrl + Left Arrow to move a selected keyframe or section backward by a single frame.
Press Ctrl + Right Arrow to move a selected keyframe or section forward by a single frame.

sequencer_playlists.label: Sequencer Playlists
sequencer_playlists.description: Official documentation on Sequencer Playlists (part of the cinematics subsystem).
keySteps: Navigate to Edit > Plugins and locate Playlists in the Virtual Production section.
Enable the Playlists plugin and restart the editor.
Navigate to Window > Virtual Production > Playlists to open the Playlists panel.
Click the Add (+) Item button to start adding Sequences to your playlist.
Assign a Sequence to the item by clicking the dropdown menu and selecting a Sequence.
Click Play All to trigger the playback of your entire playlist.

sequencer_blueprint_component.label: Sequencer Blueprint Component
sequencer_blueprint_component.description: Official documentation on Sequencer Blueprint Component.
keySteps: From the Edit menu select Plugins.
From the Plugins menu, under Built-in , enable the Actor Sequence Editor option and restart the editor when prompted.
Create a new Blueprint of the Actor type can call it Light_BP.
Inside the Light_BP , click Add Component and add a Spot Light.
Add another Component of the Actor Sequence type.
In the Details panel for the Actor Sequence , set Loop Indefinitely , Random Start Time and Auto Play , then click Open in Tab.

creating_animation_keyframes.label: Creating Animation Keyframes
creating_animation_keyframes.description: Official documentation on Creating Animation Keyframes.
keySteps: Click the Add Key button on a track.
Click the Add Key button next to a property in the selected Actor's Details panel.
Press Enter on your keyboard to place keys on the selected tracks.
Click the middle mouse button along the track's timeline to create a keyframe at the playhead's position.
Press S with an Actor selected to create a Transform Track and a keyframe with its current Location, Rotation and Scale properties.

animation_curve_editor.label: Animation Curve Editor
animation_curve_editor.description: Official documentation on Animation Curve Editor.
keySteps: Open the Curve Editor from Sequencer by clicking the Curve Editor button in the Sequencer Toolbar.
Select entries from the Outliner list to automatically filter and frame the Graph View to only display curves from that selection and any children.
Use the search bar in the Outliner to search for entries to narrow down the list.
Select tracks in the Sequencer window to cause only the selected tracks to appear in the Curve Editor Outliner.

dynamic_binding_in_sequencer.label: Dynamic Binding In Sequencer
dynamic_binding_in_sequencer.description: Official documentation on Dynamic Binding In Sequencer (part of the cinematics subsystem).
keySteps: Right-click an actor in the Hierarchy Tree.
Select Dynamic Possession > Endpoint (unbound) > Create New Endpoint or Quick Bind.
Add logic for how the binding happens in the custom Blueprint nodes (binding node and Return Node).
Right-click the blue input pin for Return Value Object and select Split Struct Pin.
Select which asset is returned from the Return Value Object dropdown menu and if that asset is possessed or spawned.

python_scripting_in_sequencer.label: Python Scripting In Sequencer
python_scripting_in_sequencer.description: Official documentation on Python Scripting In Sequencer (part of the cinematics subsystem).
keySteps: Get a Level Sequence asset using `unreal.load_asset("/Game/LevelSequenceName")`.
Open the Level Sequence in Sequencer using `unreal.LevelSequenceEditorBlueprintLibrary.open_level_sequence(level_sequence)`.
Create a frame rate object and set to the desired fps number using `frame_rate = unreal.FrameRate(numerator = 60, denominator = 1)`.
Set the display rate using `level_sequence.set_display_rate(frame_rate)`.
Set the playback range using `level_sequence.set_playback_start(20)` and `level_sequence.set_playback_end(200)`.

movie_render_pipeline.label: Movie Render Pipeline
movie_render_pipeline.description: Official documentation on Movie Render Pipeline (part of the rendering subsystem).
keySteps: Navigate in the Menu Bar to Edit > Plugins and locate the Movie Render Queue plugin in the Rendering section, or by using the Search Bar.
Enable the plugin and restart the editor.
In the Menu Bar click Window > Cinematics > Movie Render Queue .
Click the Render button and select your level sequence.
In the Settings column, click the arrow next to Unsaved Config and select Movie Render Graph  (Beta) .
Under Create New Asset , Click Movie Render Graph .

import_and_export_cinematic_fbx_animatio.label: Import And Export Cinematic Fbx Animations
import_and_export_cinematic_fbx_animatio.description: Official documentation on Import And Export Cinematic Fbx Animations.
keySteps: Determine which Level Sequence to export.
Go into the General Options and choose Export.
Use the FBX Export Options window to choose the FBX Export Compatibility version and other options.
In Maya, set the working units for Time to match the Time Rate used in Unreal Engine.
During the export process from Maya, change the export type to FBX export and the Up Axis to follow the Z-axis.
Inside the Level Sequence, right-click on the object and select Import.

spawn_temporary_actors_cinematics.label: Spawn Temporary Actors Cinematics
spawn_temporary_actors_cinematics.description: Official documentation covering spawn temporary actors (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Select the Actor that you want to spawn in the Viewport or from the Outliner.
In Sequencer, click Track > Add Actor to Sequencer > Add '{name of selected actor}'.
Right-click the Actor in Sequencer and select Convert to Spawnable.
Right-click the Spawnable bound track and locate the Spawnable category to access Spawnable Actor properties.

placing_actors.label: Placing Actors
placing_actors.description: Official documentation on Placing Actors (part of the gameplay subsystem).
keySteps: Open the Class Viewer by navigating to Tools > Class Viewer.
Select the Asset you want to place.
Drag the selected Asset into the Level Viewport.
